awd_titl_txt: Quantum Transport in Strongly Interacting Fermi Gases
awd_abstract_narration:
This program experimentally studies an optically-trapped, strongly interacting Fermi gas of Li(6) atoms as a model of universal quantum transport. This system offers unprecedented opportunities to test theoretical techniques that cross interdisciplinary boundaries, from condensed matter to nuclear matter. Measurements in ultracold Fermi gases now unite the coldest matter in the universe to the hottest matter, a quark-gluon plasma produced in gold ion collisions, which is comparable to the state of matter that existed microseconds after the Big Bang. Remarkably, both systems are found to be nearly 'perfect' fluids, in the context of a recent conjecture derived using string theory methods, with a similar ratio of viscosity to entropy density, despite a difference in temperature of 19 orders of magnitude and a difference in density of 25 orders of magnitude. 

The proposed tabletop experiments impact theories of strong interactions in intellectual disciplines well outside atomic physics, including materials science and condensed matter physics (superconductivity), nuclear physics (nuclear matter, quark-gluon plasma), high-energy physics (effective theories of strong interactions), and astrophysics (compact stellar objects). The proposed research may have practical impact in helping to determine whether it is possible to create super-high temperature nearly perfect conductors based on normal fluids, which would operate far above room temperature--materials that would enable energy-saving power lines and magnetically levitated trains. For this reason, the proposed program fits very well into national initiatives on energy and materials science.

por.por_cntn:
A central feature of this program is the measurement of quantum hydrodynamics and viscosity in strongly interacting Fermi gases. Such a gas has amazing properties, such as scale-invariant expansion, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Atoms in an initially trapped cloud act like ``balloons." When the cloud is released from an optical trap into a vacuum, the balloons expand as the cloud expands and continue to touch, in principle forever.

The Fermi gas cloud comprises just a few hundred thousand spin-up and spin-down atoms in an optical trap made of a focused laser beam. An external magnetic field controls the strength of the interaction between spin-up and spin-down atoms, which interact very strongly when the field is correctly tuned: When a pair of strongly-interacting atom clouds collide, the clouds bounce off each other and shock waves are produced, Fig. 2!

Studying this scale-invariant gas enables exploration of a remarkable conjecture from the string theory community on {\it perfect fluids}. The conjecture unifies several fields of physics and connects the hottest matter in the universe to the coldest matter. An example of a nearly perfect fluid is the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) produced in gold ion collisions. A QGP is an exotic soup of quarks and gluons, which exhibits almost perfect frictionless flow and is thought to be a good approximation to the state of matter that existed microseconds after the Big Bang. At a temperature of two trillion degrees, where even the constituents of atomic nuclei melt, a QGP is the hottest matter in the universe. It is very strongly interacting, and has tremendous density. Yet, counter to intuition, a QGP has extremely small viscosity, or stickiness, a property of nearly perfect fluids.

Remarkably, the ultracold atomic Fermi gas, at ten billionths of a degree, also exhibits nearly perfect fluidity. The atoms share a common feature with a QGP, which is nineteen orders of magnitude hotter and twenty-five orders of magnitude more dense than the Fermi gas. Both systems exhibit similar ``elliptic" flow, Fig. 3, first observed by our group, which is a consequence of extremely low viscosity. In our most recent studies, the local shear viscosity of a strongly interacting Fermi gas was measured from nearly the ground state through the superfluid transition and into the high temperature regime, for the first time, by inverting cloud-averaged elliptic flow data. The results show that a QGP and a strongly interacting Fermi gas have similar viscosity, just a few times the conjectured lower bound, when both are expressed in the natural units of Planck's constant times the density, as described in the string theory conjecture on perfect fluids. These new measurements provide benchmarks for state of the art predictions of viscosity in strongly interacting matter.


The tabletop experiments carried out in the program impact theories of strong interactions in intellectual disciplines well outside atomic physics, including materials science and condensed matter physics (superconductivity), nuclear physics (nuclear matter, quark-gluon plasma), high-energy physics (theories of strong interactions), and astrophysics
(compact stellar objects). This research on nearly perfect flow may  have
practical impact in helping to determine whether it is possible to
create super-high temperature superconductors which operate far
above room temperature--materials that would enable energy-saving
power lines and magnetically levitated trains. For this reason,
the proposed program fits very well into  national initiatives  in
materials science.
